data.title: Intro to LLM
data.statement:
Large Language Models, you see them everywhere nowadays. But how do they work? They analyze vast amounts of text data to learn the patterns and structures of language.

But really, deep down they just count the probability of the next word. That's what you will do here.

Rules:
A hyphenated word is considered as one word.
Punctuations (except hyphens) and numbers are ignored.
Letter case is ignored for the baseline word and the next words.

*Due to rounding, the output percentages may not add up to 100%.

testCases.title: Test 2
testCases.testIn:
is
Programming is nice but programming is hard. It is also creative, which is very nice.

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testIn:
and
In the vast digital landscape, programmers are the architects, weaving intricate webs of logic and creativity to construct the structures of tomorrow. With lines of code as their blueprints and algorithms as their tools, they craft solutions to problems both big and small. Like skilled artisans, they navigate the complexities of syntax, semantics, transforming abstract concepts into tangible realities. And just as a master builder takes pride in their work, programmers too find satisfaction in the elegance and efficiency of their creations. So let us celebrate the ingenuity of these modern-day craftsmen, whose innovation shapes the world we inhabit.

testCases.title: Test 3
testCases.testIn:
programming
Programming requires you to think like a gardener. You plant the seeds of code, nurture them with logic and creativity, and watch as they grow into beautiful, functional applications. Just like a well-tended garden, good programming requires patience, attention to detail, and occasional debugging to ensure everything flourishes as intended. So, let's keep cultivating those digital landscapes with care and precision!

data.constraints:
[[word]] max length of 25
[[trainingData]] max length of 1000
[[word]] always appears at least once in [[trainingData]] ignoring the letter case.
[[word]] is never the last word in [[trainingData]] if [[word]] appears only once in [[trainingData]].
data.stubGenerator:
read word:string(25)
read trainingData:string(1000)

write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1 :>> A string [[word]] - baseline word that we use to find out what word may come next.
<<Line 2 :>> A string [[trainingData]] - text that our LLM uses as training data.
data.outputDescription:
You should output the words (in lowercase) that might follow and their probability (in percentage rounded down to integer), one line for each word. Output the words in order of appearance in [[trainingData]].
The format of each line is: [[followingWord]] {{-}} [[percentage]] {{%}}

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Large Language Models, you see them everywhere nowadays. But how do they work? They analyze vast amounts of text data to learn the patterns and structures of language.

But really, deep down they just count the probability of the next word. That's what you will do here.

Rules:
A hyphenated word is considered as one word.
Punctuations (except hyphens) and numbers are ignored.
Letter case is ignored for the baseline word and the next words.

*Due to rounding, the output percentages may not add up to 100%.
Input
Line 1 : A string word - baseline word that we use to find out what word may come next.
Line 2 : A string trainingData - text that our LLM uses as training data.
Output
You should output the words (in lowercase) that might follow and their probability (in percentage rounded down to integer), one line for each word. Output the words in order of appearance in trainingData.
The format of each line is: followingWord - percentage %
Constraints
word max length of 25
trainingData max length of 1000
word always appears at least once in trainingData ignoring the letter case.
word is never the last word in trainingData if word appears only once in trainingData.
Example
Input
hi
Hi Barbie. Hi Ken.
Output
barbie - 50 %
ken - 50 %
